'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-11-26 19:11:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

@Chmouel: By deprecated I at least mean that it will always be limited to the v2 API which will be officially deprecated in the Icehouse release. There is no problems making refinements here though. 

@Tristan: Unfortunately this is actually something we used to do and have had to remove. The problem being that whilst UUIDs are 'generally' used for ID it does not have to be the case. Specific example, if you back onto an LDAP server then user ids are your username.

The real problem i think here is the use of the name_or_id variable. We should be passing either the name (in which case we do a find) or the id (in which case we do a get) but i'm not sure if the client can be made to make that distinction."}, {'account_id': 9311, 'date': '2013-11-27 10:01:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Jamie: I just doubled check on a devstack with a ldap backend for keystone. It seems to work like a sql backend, user_uid shown in user-list are valid for a get() while user_name will return a NotFound exception.

I understand there have been a simplification of the CLI interface, allowing user_uid or user_name to be used seamlessly. Yet the server shouldn't warn it 'Could not find user' where it is just a wrong id."}, {'account_id': 9311, 'date': '2013-11-29 16:16:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Jamie sorry, my bad, if users are manually added in ldap database, uid are indeed user name.

Besides (re-)adding a "--name" / "--id" in CLI, I'm out of luck then.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-12-05 17:25:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Do not merge

the current approach is by design. perhaps the warning on the service side should be demoted to an info?'}, {'account_id': 9311, 'date': '2013-12-09 16:07:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

The warning on the service side is performed in a generic way there:
  https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/common/wsgi.py#L242

Moreover, so far I found those exceptions to be logged incorrectly: ServiceNotFound, ProjectNotFound, RoleNotFound and UserNotFound.
  (Produced with keystone client action: "service-get", "tenant-get", "role-get", "user-get").
There may be more, but those objects are easily used with name instead of id.

I don't think we should add specifics except handlers for those as there is no way to know for sure if it is an ID not found, or just a name lookup.
Maybe I could clarify the exception's message, from "Could not find role, %(role_id)s." to "Could not find role id, %(role_id)s." ?
I think this would help and shouldn't break anything.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-12-17 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-12-17 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Makes find_resource aware if param is id or name

find_resource tries to get object by their id, and only when it fails
it will do a search by name. This produces an unecessary warning on
the server side: 'Could not find user/role'. This fix adds an is_uuid
method in keystoneclient.utils and makes according request whenever
param is an id or a name.

Change-Id: I84c3c8f3b6d1899b538809335863e887fe41837b
Closes-Bug: #1252291

commit_message:
Make rebuild use new-style BDMs

Rebuild call needs to be using new style BDMs as since the change
I5b9c3e2d959c602fa22f49db681da918ae0adcea the _prep_block_device method
of the compute manager class can accept only new style BDMs.

This patch removes the DB call for BDMs from the API side and RPCs None
instead (a valid value all version know how to handle), so that we can
make sure that the new style BDMs are retrieved from the conductor on
the compute side, without having to bump the RPC versions. The compute
node will do this regardless of whether the client side actually sent
them, so that upgraded nodes do not regress.

Closes-bug: 1241615
blueprint: clean-up-legacy-block-device-mapping

Change-Id: Ibe49ec2ec5151191f3887bb9c7b9d296e79fad5e

subject: Make rebuild use new-style BDMs

commit_message:
Make rebuild use new-style BDMs

Rebuild call needs to be using new style BDMs as since the change
I5b9c3e2d959c602fa22f49db681da918ae0adcea the _prep_block_device method
of the compute manager class can accept only new style BDMs.

This patch removes the DB call for BDMs from the API side and RPCs None
instead (a valid value all version know how to handle), so that we can
make sure that the new style BDMs are retrieved from the conductor on
the compute side, without having to bump the RPC versions. The compute
node will do this regardless of whether the client side actually sent
them, so that upgraded nodes do not regress.

Closes-bug: 1241615
blueprint: clean-up-legacy-block-device-mapping

Change-Id: Ibe49ec2ec5151191f3887bb9c7b9d296e79fad5e
(cherry picked from commit aafee652f808f68ef38d8950a05242d578f5e8a5)

commit_message:
add missing "roles" list to token spec

The request/response examples in the later part of the doc include roles
in scoped tokens, but the attribute definition section of the document
neglected to mention them entirely.

Change-Id: I6511da6a9f032f7a28fd85fe141a29b786b39951

commit_message:
Allow django >=1.6

This should not pass testing with the current state of horizon and
django 1.6. We want this change to fail tests as confirmation of that.

Change-Id: Icbbd2690b7c1b953b3b6f3acba7368580f9c50d5

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-12 20:49:12.000000000', 'message': 'Report thin volume capacity correctly

Thin LVM volumes require a different capacity calculation.  New volumes are
created from the thin pool (not the volume group like normal LVM volumes), so
the size of the thin pool much be considered instead of the containing volume
group.  In addition, thin volumes can be overcommitted so capacity does not
necessarily decrease when a new volume is created.

This patch gets us to a working thin LVM volume implementation by always
reporting total and free capacity as the size of the thin pool.  There are
certainly alternative implementations, but this serves as a starting point for
further discussion.

Change-Id: I8a2b8ce972cb0a585555dd92c78dd8bbade1a9b2
Closes-Bug: #1249782

'}, {'created': '2013-12-05 20:20:48.000000000', 'message': "LVM: report thin pool capacity in a reasonable way

Now that thin pools are created of adequate size, capacity reporting
must be updated so that users can successfully create new volumes.  The
existing code reports the size and remaining capacity of the volume
group.  When 'thin' is enabled, the thin pool takes up nearly all of the
volume group and available capacity appears to be 0 - preventing any new
volumes from being created.

This patch changes thin LVM capacity reporting to always report
available capacity as the total size of the thin pool.  For users, this
means a couple of things:

  1. No single volume can exceed the size of the thin pool.
  2. An infinite number of volumes can be created, all backed by the
     same thin pool.

This allows infinite over-provisioning of thin LVM.  It is left to the
user to monitor the actual free space remaining in the pool and make use
of thin volumes accordingly.

Additional improvements are being considered, so expect updates to this
logic in the near future.

Change-Id: I8a2b8ce972cb0a585555dd92c78dd8bbade1a9b2
Closes-Bug: #1249782
"}]
commit_message:
LVM: report thin pool capacity in a reasonable way

Now that thin pools are created of adequate size, capacity reporting
must be updated so that users can successfully create new volumes.  The
existing code reports the size and remaining capacity of the volume
group.  When 'thin' is enabled, the thin pool takes up nearly all of the
volume group and available capacity appears to be 0 - preventing any new
volumes from being created.

This patch changes thin LVM capacity reporting to always report
available capacity as the total size of the thin pool.  For users, this
means a couple of things:

  1. No single volume can exceed the size of the thin pool.
  2. An infinite number of volumes can be created, all backed by the
     same thin pool.

This allows infinite over-provisioning of thin LVM.  It is left to the
user to monitor the actual free space remaining in the pool and make use
of thin volumes accordingly.

Additional improvements are being considered, so expect updates to this
logic in the near future.

Change-Id: I8a2b8ce972cb0a585555dd92c78dd8bbade1a9b2
Closes-Bug: #1249782

@Joe, hope you don't mind, i uploaded a new patch that cleaned up some formatting issues..."}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-10-16 04:31:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Joe, strictly changed white space issues, that was all.'}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2013-10-16 09:23:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This API is too federation protocol specific. It only caters for SAML, which means that when new federation protocols are added e.g. ABFAB or OpenID Connect, then new APIs will be needed. Instead this should be a federation API, not a SAML API. In essence there is no difference to Keystone whether the user authenticated against a SAML IDP, ABFAB IDP, OpenID IDP etc. Only the token syntax is different, but the contents should be conceptually the same"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-10-16 14:42:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Agree with David Chadwick.  The right approach is going to be somewhere between this and his federation API proposal.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-10-16 14:42:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-10-17 20:55:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

this needs to link in with the mapping API: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20331/'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-10-18 05:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-18 05:24:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-10-18 05:26:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Readers,

for patch set 3, I mostly made formatting changes and split the IDP & SAML2 work. 

I'm thinking that I should have removed the mapping portion too... 

Going to do another draft tmrw"}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2013-10-18 13:17:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Here are some ideas for your next version
1. When adding a new IDP, have an "any" field that can be used to add IDP specific metadata that is needed to talk to this IDP. The precise nature of its contents will be federation protocol specific. Protocol profiles can then specify the contents of this for each federation protocol

2. Remove the notion of attribute mapping from the token obtaining interface. This should be hidden from the API user. The input should be an assertion from an IDP, and the output should be a Keystone token. How this is achieved is left up to the implementation of the API.

3. Consider having a separate attribute mapping API, in which the input is a set of IDP validated attributes and the output is a mapped set of Keystone attributes. This API can be called by the implementation of API 2. above.

4. Dont have a SAML interface for obtaining tokens, but rather have a federation interface for obtaining tokens. The input will be an assertion from an IDP in some federation protocol language, and the output will be a keystone token'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-10-19 02:38:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with David's general statements.

Which auth format used is going to be dependent on the  plugin to the keystone/auth controller.  Each of the federation protocols should be represented there, and only the Federation specific logic should be in that plugin.  There will likely be a Federation base class for those plugins.  While none of that will be reflected in the API doc, keep it in mind when writing what should be in the API.

The configuration of Mapping is going to be handled by a separate extension.  These extensions should probably reference the mapping extension"}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-10-19 04:31:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-19 04:31:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Ad 2. What I suggested was:
  - Keep all CRD (U not required) operations for both *public_ keys* and supported *protocols*. Otherwise, I can add supported protocols, but cannot remove them.
  - Make *protocols* and *public_keys* IdentityProvider's attributes immutable, because they should be managed via GET/PUT/DELETE HTTP requests.

I was also thinking about keeping protocol specific (if there is any) data in the protocol entity, not IdP itself. Comments?

So it would look like:

### Setting protocol support to an identity provider: `PUT /OS-IDP/identity_providers/{idp_id}/proto
cols`
	
	Request:
	
	    {
	        "protocols": [
	            {
	                "name": "saml2"
                        "data": { key-value dict }
	            },
	            {
	                "name": "openId"
                        "data": { key-value dict }
	            }
	        ],
	    }


Comments on that?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-11-20 09:25:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Works for me

"}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2013-11-20 19:52:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Responses to Some remarks of Steve:

1) in the etherpad, there is an attribute for IdPs: level of assurance - can anyone give any more information on this? Is it needed for our first pass?


More info: LoA specifies the assurance (aka trust/reliance) you can have in the way the IdP authenticated the end user. It is a dynamic parameter passed in some federation protocols such as SAML.
Why is it needed? The cloud service provider needs to be able to limit or control the trust that it places in external IdPs. This is why I have proposed that we have various CSP trust policies such as: which IdPs to trust, which attributes to trust them to issue etc. So another trust policy can be, How much do I trust a particular IDP to authenticate its users? The value placed in the CSP's LOA policy will be the maximum value that will be accepted from the IDP in its authentication assertions. If the value (say in a SAML assertion) is lower than that in the LOA trust policy, then it will be accepted, but if it is higher, then it will be downgraded to the maximum value that is trusted. This is to stop a potential escalation of privileges by the IDP, because some PDP policies may include the LOA in its rules e.g. to read a data item the user needs to be authenticated to LOA 2, but to modify a data item the user needs to be authenticated to LOA 3. If the CSP admin does not trust a particular IDP to authenticate users to greater than say LOA 2, this would prohibit users from this IDP being allowed to update the data item. But if the IDP asserted an LOA of 3, then without the LOA trust policy the user would be able to modify the data item.


2) Marek recommended that we have just PUT for IdP supported protocols, any arguments there?

I dont see why dynamic variation of IDP protocols is special and needs any special treatment. Either we support the dynamic addition of IDPs to a running Keystone (in which case we support CRUD for IDP management) or we do not support dynamic management and require IDPs to be configured via config files. So I dont support Marek's recommendation without further justification for this.


3) We decided that mappings should live on their own, but we don't have a way to associate mapping and idp. I'm assuming a new attribute for the IdP?

I question why mappings need to be tied to IDPs. I dont think they do in general. Mappings should be from asserted identity attributes (regardless of the IDP) to Keystone authz attributes. It might be that in certain configurations each IDP asserts different identity attributes to the other IDPs and therefore there are separate mapping rules for each IDP, but in this case you dont need to tie the mapping to the IDP since no other IDP will issue the same identity attributes anyway. In the academic case, we can have hundreds of IDPs which issue the same attributes (the EduPerson schema attributes) so in this case we definitely do not want to ties attributes to IDPs. The only time I could forsee that you might want to tie mappings to an IDP is if two different IDPs issue the same identity attributes, but you only wish to accept the attributes from one of the IDPs. However, this is already catered for in the Attribute Issuing Policy which says which IDPs are trusted to issue which attributes. Therefore I can see no technical reason for tying mappings to IDPs.


4) Do we support CRUD for attribute type and attribute type/value mapping?

I think we should support CRUD for all attribute mappings or for none. In our different implementations, we have CRUD, or we have config files. Kristy says that it is actually much easier to manage a Keystone implementation that does not support CRUD and only supports config files. But for flexibility I think we should support CRUD APIs for all mappings, even if some implementations dont wish to support it.


5) Do we support having a set of limited attributes from the IdP side - for the first pass?

Sorry but I dont understand this question. Some points to note. a) we cannot control in general which attributes an IDP will issue b) we can control which attributes we will trust by having an Attribute Issuing Policy."}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-11-20 19:56:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (5 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2013-11-20 20:13:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I would like you to revert to the original federation API that Kent published for the request and validation phases. These are

  Request:

{
	"auth": {
		"identity": {
			"federated": {
				"phase": "request",
				"protocol": "<protocol>",
				"protocol_data": [<any protocol specific data>],
				"provider_id": "<provider-id>"
			},
			"methods": [
				"federated"
			]
		}
	}
}



Request:
{
      "auth": {
		"identity": {
			"methods": [
				"federated"
			],
			"federated": {
				"phase": "validate",
				"provider_id": "<provider-id>",
				"protocol": "<protocol>",
				"protocol_data": [<any specific protocol data>]
			}
		}
	}
}

You simply replace <protocol> with SAML in order to provide the SAML API.'}, {'account_id': 1228, 'date': '2013-11-21 00:49:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 994, 'date': '2013-11-21 00:55:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 5956, 'date': '2013-11-21 14:32:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

I wanted to clarify David's point about our experience with attribute mapping CRUD vs config files, when testing the two implementations I found that it is easier to add and keep track of complex rules in an XML file than using a CRUD interface. It's hard to get a broad overview of what rules you have put in place without a number of create and read operations, with a file it is all in front of you.

However, it has to be said that file based systems suffer from scalability issues, and a CRUD system with a decent interface could eliminate the problem."}, {'account_id': 994, 'date': '2013-11-21 22:13:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (6 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-11-28 22:00:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: (8 inline comments)

Too many comments! But I appreciate all the input! I've replied to some of the smaller issues with inline comments. I'll upload a new patch soon.


@DavidChadwick

1) Thanks for the information, it certainly gives me ideas for how to treat and implement this going forward, but i think we're going to not require this for the first pass of the implemention.

2) My fault for not giving enough information the first time around, we were wondering if it's best to support full CRUD for adding/removing the 'supported_protocols' of an IdP, or just having a PUT method, that over-rides whatever is there.

3) OK - I think we're on the same page here - mappings will live on their own in /v3/OS-MAP/mappings (or something similar). But at the idp level, we will have an attribute, when adding a protocol, that has a mapping_id that the idp wishes to use. More info here: https://gist.github.com/dolph/7567024

4) OK - again, we're on the same page - If we did support CRUD, it would be for all attribute mappings. We were just wondering if it's better to support full CRUD or just supporting a PUT method that over-rides it. I think we'll end up going the full CRUD route, as you suggested, it provides better flexibility. 

5) How did Kent show or update how what attributes were trusted? 

6) Auth request - Originally Kent has the provider_id and protocol in the auth request, can't we determine these from the protocol_data?"}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-11-29 00:44:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-11-29 00:44:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Works for me

Just to clarify the requirement values:

1. any_value_of should return TRUE when the specified type is matched regardless of the value, and FALSE if the attribute type is not present.
2. any_one_of should return TRUE if if one or more of the specified values for the specified type is present and otherwise FALSE.
3. not_any_of should return TRUE if none of the specified values for the specified type are present and otherwise FALSE.'}, {'account_id': 1228, 'date': '2013-12-03 15:21:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Looks good mostly. I am not completely clear on the difference between 'GET /' and 'GET /v3/'."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-12-06 22:29:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-12-06 22:31:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-06 22:31:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-noop http://logs.openstack.org/76/60576/3/check/gate-noop/d541582 : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-12-08 23:25:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Whilst in the implementation we have /v3 and /v2.0 these prefixes are mount points rather than part of the actual v2 or v3 API. I therefore don't think we should include the /v3 as part of the API doc.

I think put the unversioned / response in it's own file."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-12-09 15:23:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Jamie: disagree. GET /v3/ represents the root of this API, so it definitely belongs in this API's namespace and it provides functionality that v3 clients must consume to do minor version detection, etc. GET / definitely falls outside the scope of this API, so I simply alluded to it's presence & purpose here, although it's not really required for a v3 client."}, {'account_id': 220, 'date': '2013-12-09 19:39:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-12-09 20:00:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-12-09 23:34:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-12-10 00:51:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Dolph: Disagree. The standard discovery means for determining the API endpoint should be to hit / and get back a list of supported versions and the URLs that they are on. Presented here is the V3 URL which happens to be on /v3/. I should use that URL as the basis for issuing API requests. 

That is a distinct split between what is provided (http://localhost:35357/v3) and the API that i must know about to talk to that URL (/users/X). If the base url was provided as http://localhost:35357/latest or http://v3.localhost:35357/ i'm not expected to append a /v3 onto that."}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-12-10 00:54:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

All of that is not to say that we shouldn't be documenting the response from GET /v3/ it's just that in the context of the v3 API that response _is_ GET / and that we shouldn't be namespacing the API doc with /v3/"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-12-17 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-12-17 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Added versioned endpoint description

Nothing in this commit is proposing anything new, but rather describing
the existing behavior of the unversioned endpoint and the
behavior/structure of v3's versioned endpoint response.

Also added explicit `/v3/` on documented resources in the API to more
clearly differentiate from `/` and `/v3/` throughout the document.

Change-Id: Ibf6342f035578a3c2dfebdc440ef6512221057b7

This seems to be a just doing a cross-backend copy to block store... 

1) That is not really the intent of backup... migrate/clone/snapshot are better interfaces for that

So I agree with Duncan here. This backup driver appears to do exactly what is provided by a volume clone. So the first question is what value does this actually add to what we already have and secondly, what is your criteria for a backup? If the user is using the Nexenta driver for their volumes they would be backing up to the same data store that contains their volumes came from which is not a backup in the sense that the copy is protected from any failure that may occur to the original.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-10-31 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: Abandoned

commit_message:
Nexenta backup service

This patch adds 'nexenta' backup driver to support any type of cinder
volume backup/restore to/from NexentaStor backend. The driver should
support all types of volumes to be backed up to and restored from
NexentaStor backend. This will be done naively as we don't know any
specifics about volume to be backed up.

Implements: blueprint volume-backup-nexenta-backend
Change-Id: I33516672c0929e2f3babdd3184ea747455e89472

commit_message:
Allows using interger values for project enabled

The code was already converting the integer to the correct boolean
value. The problem was that it did this in a copy of the project
reference dictionary, but used the original when making the
create/update calls. The data would be successfully stored, but a
traceback would be raised when fetching from the data store.

Closes-Bug #1199652
Change-Id: I777e7c6577a5c0773458758ed457e9a19d20c9f4

commit_message:
Policy based domain isolation can't be defined.

Policy based domain isolation is not possible on token
APIs due to lack of domain_id in policy_dict for API target

Closes-Bug: 1233874
Closes-Bug: 1251048

Change-Id: I855ec8ff4899ba3797a2e2bb23945ab4b23d2bea

[{'created': '2013-12-11 14:38:24.000000000', 'message': "Prevent spoofing instance_id from neturon to nova

Previously, one could update a port's device_id in neutron to be
that of another tenant's instance_id and then be able to retrieve
that instance's metadata. This patch prevents this from occuring by
checking that X-Tenant-ID received from the metadata request matches
the tenant_id in the nova database.

DocImpact - This patch is dependent on another patch in neutron
            which adds X-Tenant-ID to the request. Therefore to
            minimize downtime one should upgrade Neutron first (then
            restart neutron-metadata-agent) and lastly update nova.

Change-Id: I93bf662797c3986324ca2099b403833c2e990fb4
Closes-Bug: #1235450

commit_message:
Prevent spoofing instance_id from neutron to nova

Previously, one could update a port's device_id in neutron to be
that of another tenant's instance_id and then be able to retrieve
that instance's metadata. This patch prevents this from occurring by
checking that X-Tenant-ID received from the metadata request matches
the tenant_id in the nova database.

DocImpact - This patch is dependent on another patch in neutron
            which adds X-Tenant-ID to the request. Therefore to
            minimize downtime one should upgrade Neutron first (then
            restart neutron-metadata-agent) and lastly update nova.

Change-Id: I93bf662797c3986324ca2099b403833c2e990fb4
Closes-Bug: #1235450

commit_message:
Revert "glance-manage should work like nova-manage"

This change has a bug that does not seem to take version option into
consideration. A fix for the same bug has been submitted for review at
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/60188/1. However while adding unit
tests to glance-manage oslo.cfg reset doesnt seem to work properly and
all the subsequent tests seem to fail. Untill the tests are fixed
reverting this change to avoid broken functionality.

This reverts commit 7e6319d95554413f1a0856603f434c9c60b8d256

Change-Id: I1d821ef75b4a77499579f18a6f211aac136132f5

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-06 01:37:32.000000000', 'message': "Forbidden update message diffs images/tasks/member

On an forbidden update, the message returned to the user
is not tied to the type of object modified by the operation.
For example: a forbidden image member update will return
`You are not permitted to modify 'status' on this image.`
instead of image_member.

This patch fixes the issue for images, image members and tasks.

Change-Id: Ie9774807f0190a517a619aeb56c1398741ac4407
Closes-Bug: #1250228
"}, {'created': '2013-12-06 19:47:50.000000000', 'message': "Forbidden update message diffs images/tasks/member

commit_message:
Forbidden update message diffs images/tasks/member

On an forbidden update, the message returned to the user
is not tied to the type of object modified by the operation.
For example: a forbidden image member update will return
`You are not permitted to modify 'status' on this image.`
instead of image_member.

This patch fixes the issue for images, image members and tasks.

Change-Id: Ie9774807f0190a517a619aeb56c1398741ac4407
Closes-Bug: #1250228

commit_message:
Rename instance_type to flavor in nova.network tree

Renames 'instance_type' to 'flavor' in the nova.network tree along with
related tests.

Note that 'instance_type_id' is part of the Instance table in the data
model and is not touched as part of this change.

Part of blueprint flavor-instance-type-dedup

Change-Id: I7319315daa77b7334f6d5509cf87faa71148f8ef

commit_message:
Add missing argument max_size in libvirt driver

max_size argument was added in commit 3cdfe894ab58f7b91bf7fb690fc5bc724e44066f,
but missing  in _create_ephemeral and _create_swap method, which cause
exception raised when caching ephemeral and swap disk files of the instance.

Add test for _create_ephemeral used with max_size parameter
and test _create_swap method

Closes-Bug: 1251152
Closes-Bug: 1250032
(cherry picked from commit 384f55bcb32251698cc2ce839a0286ef99e74984)

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/test_libvirt.py
	nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py

Change-Id: I46032ad32f317c923692b8b3d40cedd0dce06cad

commit_message:
Make ec2 use Flavor object

This makes the ec2 API use the Flavor object directly. Note that
it also corrects some old usage of non-object instances along
the way.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects

Change-Id: Ic13746e085169b6cc0a25fa815c6894a8020c437

subject: Move restore and rebuild operations to Flavor objects

'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-12-04 16:09:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

A few things:

1. I think you missed a spot in the compute manager.

2. The commit says this is for resize and rebuild, but there are changes to restore in there.

3. The test changes only touch on rebuild test cases it looks like, what about resize/restore test case changes?  Since my browser won't expand the test_compute.py diff, I can't see what else is in there that maybe needs to change.

4. Shouldn't the test_compute changes be using objects now instead of old school dicts for the fake instances?

5. Are you going to address the (non-voting) pylint errors?

2013-11-22 20:40:38.675 | Unique errors reported by pylint: was 116, now 118.
2013-11-22 20:40:38.675 | nova/compute/api.py:2214: [E1120, API._reverse_upsize_quota_delta] No value passed for parameter 'id' in function call
2013-11-22 20:40:38.675 | 
2013-11-22 20:40:38.676 | nova/compute/api.py:2212: [E1120, API._reverse_upsize_quota_delta] No value passed for parameter 'id' in function call"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-12-04 16:51:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I think 1 and 2 are related to the mistake in the commit message mentioning resize instead of restore.

3: The restore cases are structured such that they're not affected by the change. When converting stuff to objects, I like to keep the tests as untouched as possible to show that nothing is behaving differently.

4. Um, I'm not sure what you mean. It was using a real object, but it was getting it a roundabout way. I have changed it to be direct, so see if that looks better when I submit.

5. No. Pylint is massively confused by objects such that it's completely useless now, IMHO."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-12-04 17:01:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Just as a note to myself, looks like restore/rebuild don't touch the compute manager or conductor here, they will when resize gets changed to use flavor objects."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-12-04 17:02:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-12-04 17:37:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Move restore and rebuild operations to Flavor objects

This makes the compute_api restore and rebuild operations use
Flavor objects for their reservation and record-keeping activities.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects

Change-Id: If55294e0e1ce678448ee0e9e11fc7b64b5a73386

subject: Add flavor access methods to Instance object

I noticed tempest failed, I think you hit bug(s):

We don't automatically recheck or reverify, so please consider
doing that manually if someone hasn't already. For a code review

commit_message:
Add flavor access methods to Instance object

This adds a native interface to the Instance object to get, save, and
delete either the main or stashed flavors. This will let us migrate
code away from flavors.py and also provide us a versioned method to
handle conversion of flavors, flavor extra specs, and system_metadata
to the JSON blob that we have planned.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects

Change-Id: I13a4903460b05798e9c95b2148fe93e4963d6361

commit_message:
3PAR FC: add ability to add WWNs to host

When a host is created on the HP 3PAR array,
at initialize connection time, the host is
created with all WWNs provided in the connector
structure. However, the driver did not have
the ability to add new WWNs after a host is created.

This patch adds the ability to add WWNs to a
host, at initialize connection time, if a new
WWN is provided in the connector structure.

Change-Id: I6fd8a5511f83d5460da30ff5558a3e95964a95f5
Closes-bug: 1258229

commit_message:
Correct invalid docstrings

Several warnings and errors are reported when the Keystone
documentation is built because the docstrings are not valid
reStructuredText. This makes it more difficult than necessary
for developers to validate that new changes are correct.

This change corrects the docstrings so that there are fewer
warnings and errors.

Change-Id: I2000a02d5d374749b2c611e63743d542b74e7fa0

the nvplib call is already tested: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/tests/unit/nicira/test_nvplib.py#L215

In nicira unit tests, the result of the operation on the backend is never verified (also because the backend is stubbed out, so there's little point to verify something which is mocked anyway).

commit_message:
NVP: propagate net-gw update to backend

When a network gateway's name is updated, propagate the
update to the backend.

Closes-Bug: #1261334
Change-Id: Icaae84e7f5373946e8c82e0e519528409925dd9d

subject: Include lswitch id in NSX plugin port mappings

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-30 16:34:40.000000000', 'message': "Include lswitch id in NSX plugin port mappings

This patch adds the logical switch identifier in the model class
for describing mappings between neutron and nsx switch ports.
This will allow for a better handling of the chained logical switch
use case.

This patch also moves the routines for retrieving nsx identifiers
in a separate module in preparation for the introduction of async
operations and renames relevant model classes, attributes, and
functions from 'nvp' to 'nsx'.

Related to blueprint nvp-async-backend-communication

Change-Id: I5fa1e8f0d863b7d1fc278ffdeac8acc076a843e8
"}, {'created': '2013-10-30 16:58:01.000000000', 'message': "Include lswitch id in NSX plugin port mappings

This patch adds the logical switch identifier in the model class
for describing mappings between neutron and nsx switch ports.
This will allow for a better handling of the chained logical switch
use case.

This patch also moves the routines for retrieving nsx identifiers
in a separate module in preparation for the introduction of async
operations and renames relevant model classes, attributes, and
functions from 'nvp' to 'nsx'.

Related to blueprint nvp-async-backend-communication

Change-Id: I5fa1e8f0d863b7d1fc278ffdeac8acc076a843e8
"}, {'created': '2013-11-11 01:53:55.000000000', 'message': "Include lswitch id in NSX plugin port mappings

This patch adds the logical switch identifier in the model class
for describing mappings between neutron and nsx switch ports.
This will allow for a better handling of the chained logical switch
use case.

This patch also moves the routines for retrieving nsx identifiers
in a separate module in preparation for the introduction of async
operations and renames relevant model classes, attributes, and
functions from 'nvp' to 'nsx'.

Related to blueprint nvp-async-backend-communication

Change-Id: I5fa1e8f0d863b7d1fc278ffdeac8acc076a843e8

commit_message:
Include lswitch id in NSX plugin port mappings

This patch adds the logical switch identifier in the model class
for describing mappings between neutron and nsx switch ports.
This will allow for a better handling of the chained logical switch
use case.

This patch also moves the routines for retrieving nsx identifiers
in a separate module in preparation for the introduction of async
operations and renames relevant model classes, attributes, and
functions from 'nvp' to 'nsx'.

Related to blueprint nvp-async-backend-communication
Related to blueprint nicira-plugin-renaming

Change-Id: I5fa1e8f0d863b7d1fc278ffdeac8acc076a843e8

scheduler unit tests to use mock exclusively.

commit_message:
Use mock for scheduler tests

In our effort to move from mox to mock, this patch will convert the
scheduler unit tests to use mock exclusively.  Also fixed some pylint
errors along the way.

Change-Id: If5a94838981a04a38c2797ced07f23abfafbedb7

[{'created': '2013-12-09 15:58:21.000000000', 'message': 'NVP plugin: Avoid timeouts if creating routers in parallel

There is a well-known issue of eventlet causing deadlocks with
mysql transactions; such condition might occur when
creating NVP routers in parallel.

To avoid this, this patch moves the long-running method
_update_router_gw_info outside of the mysql transaction, adding
the appropriate failure management code, and adds a lock to the
method _nvp_create_ext_gw_port, to ensure serial access to it.

commit_message:
NVP plugin: Avoid timeouts if creating routers in parallel

There is a well-known issue of eventlet causing deadlocks with
mysql transactions; such condition might occur when
creating NVP routers in parallel.

To avoid this, this patch moves the long-running method
_update_router_gw_info outside of the mysql transaction, adding
the appropriate failure management code, and adds a lock to the
method _nvp_create_ext_gw_port, to ensure serial access to it.

Unit tests for verifying correct behaviour in case of failures
are added as well.

Closes Bug: #1251847

Change-Id: I2864e2f5bfd3982875ef9df97186f64a9fcaa0e0

commit_message:
db: fix duplicate entry detection

On some versions of SQLite, the exception reporting the IntegrityError
has a different message than the one actually looked for.
This patch adds this version and the ability to look for different
regexps at the same time to match exceptions.

Change-Id: I1faa94ac6b1ac20482e8bb314bd8430b2d69e2eb

Reasons:
 - tox update v1.6

Changes:
 - tox 1.6 allows us to skip the sdist step, which is slow.
 - It also allows us to override the install line. In this case, it's
   important as it allows us to stop getting pre-release software we
   weren't asking for.

Original patch by Monty Taylor, talked about here:

commit_message:
Updates tox.ini to use new features

Reasons:
 - tox update v1.6

Changes:
 - tox 1.6 allows us to skip the sdist step, which is slow.
 - It also allows us to override the install line. In this case, it's
   important as it allows us to stop getting pre-release software we
   weren't asking for.

Original patch by Monty Taylor, talked about here:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-September/015495.html

Change-Id: I8a8fdd420eceb5b702e7d9eedd8b5be341d3f56e

commit_message:
[Netapp/Nexenta] Move registration of config options

This doesn't really make a difference in practice, but
makes it possible for the sample config generator to figure
out the config group relationship when options are in one
file.

Change-Id: I3bc6ab5bcc85a8c11c9261b0d8c520fb846a7864

Since this change touches many files, we should probably get the PTL's nod on this as well before merging (we should try to minimize any changes that can potentially disrupt any ongoing efforts around the neutron stability efforts; not to say that this merge will)."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-12-11 13:49:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

why doesnot oslo implement  uuidutils.generate_uuid() with str(uuid.uuid4()) so that other project does not need to do change?

Just a question."}, {'account_id': 2711, 'date': '2013-12-12 05:21:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I think maybe we should intervene to discuss this kind of olso design desision when it was made in the initial time in the page http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-November/018980.html, it is beyond the scope for this patch.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-12-12 13:40:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I personally am not in favor of this patch and voted -1 against it in nova.
It is nice that we have a standard. If we are going to go ahead with the patch then lets at least have a utility function so that the change set is really just the imports - that was the original code and then that was changed to generate_uuid ...."}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-12-16 21:58:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with gary as well here."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-12-17 02:55:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

We had a similar discussion. Honestly speaking, I don't have a strong opinion on whether str(uuid.uuid4()) vs a utility method. Though a utility method helps us to use a consistent way, even if we introduce a utility method, we can't remove str(uuid.uuid4()) completely."}, {'account_id': 2711, 'date': '2013-12-17 03:40:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Abandoned

Thank you for your all reviews, personly I don't think it's necessary as well, I submitted this patch is only because my another patch is commented to pay attension to it by other reviewers. so abandon this change.
Finally just want to remind some of the same changes have been merged into repository both in other projects and some parts of the neutron project."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-25 09:46:11.000000000', 'message': 'Replace uuidutils.generate_uuid() with str(uuid.uuid4())

Oslo is deprecating/removing uuidutils during the icehouse cycle.
Consequently we need to remove all references to uuidutils, and
replace them with the corresponding function from neutron.

Change-Id: If7d377b28fcd9f557f5d42afba241ae48a19e36b
Partial-Bug: #1253497

commit_message:
Replace uuidutils.generate_uuid() with str(uuid.uuid4())

Oslo is deprecating/removing uuidutils during the icehouse cycle.
Consequently we need to remove all references to uuidutils, and
replace them with the corresponding function from neutron.

Change-Id: If7d377b28fcd9f557f5d42afba241ae48a19e36b
Partial-Bug: #1253497

All of the GET responses contain expires_at, which from speaking

commit_message:
Correct OS-TRUST extension expires_at responses

All of the GET responses contain expires_at, which from speaking
to the original author I understand is an ommission to the docs
due to the code getting subsequently updated.

So to align the docs with the real API responses, add an expires_at
to each of the example responses.

Change-Id: Ifdfb9df04c730cf2f79a5e79daccf9a24342556d
